**Transcript**:
With his harebrained schemes 
and asinine dealings with the gods, King Midas ruled the ancient kingdom 
of Phrygia with an uneven hand. He was known in Greek mythology 
as a rogue ruler whose antics bemused his people 
and distracted the gods. Midas spent his days 
in a stupor of splendor, spoiling himself and his beloved daughter
and gorging himself on feasts and wine. Unsurprisingly, he felt 
an affinity with Dionysus, god of wine, carnival, and performance. One day, Midas discovered a satyr dozing in his rose garden and drunk 
on more than the scent of flowers. Midas recognized the satyr 
as one of Dionysus’s followers and let him nurse 
his hangover at the palace. Pleased with the king’s hospitality,
Dionysus offered to grant him one wish. Midas cast a greedy eye 
over his surroundings. Despite the luxury in which he lived, no amount of precious jewels, finest silk 
or splendid decor felt like enough. His life, he thought, was lacking luster;
what he needed was more gold. The god sent the power to turn anything
the king touched to gold surging through Midas. Ecstatic, he turned to his possessions. At his lightest touch, 
the palace walls transformed, stone statues shone, and goblets glittered. He galloped through his home in a frenzy, handling each item until 
it took on a lustrous sheen. Soon the palace heaved with gold, and Midas’s delirious
laughter echoed off the walls. Exhausted and hungry from his rampage, Midas picked up a bunch of grapes from 
his newly gilded fruit bowl. But he nearly shattered his teeth, for the fruit had turned 
to metal in his mouth. When he picked up a loaf of bread, 
the crumbs hardened in his hand. Flinging himself onto 
his bed in frustration, Midas discovered his plush pillows 
had morphed into solid gold. Hearing his cries of frustration, 
his daughter entered the room. But when Midas reached out to her, he saw with horror that he had frozen her 
into a golden statue. Horrified at what he had done, Midas begged the gods 
to rid him of his power. Taking pity on the foolish king, Dionysus told Midas to wash 
his hands in the River Pactolus. When Midas reached into the river, 
the gold drained from his fingertips. Midas returned home 
to find his daughter alive and his palace back to normal, 
and he rejoiced. You’d think he would’ve learned 
his lesson, but just a few weeks later,
Midas blundered again, insulting the music and sun god Apollo 
when he declared Pan a greater musician. Apollo scornfully declared that the king 
must have the ears of an ass to make such a misjudgment,
and transformed Midas accordingly. Once again regretting his behavior, Midas kept his hairy ears 
hidden in public. They were seen only by his barber, who was sworn to secrecy during 
a very awkward grooming session. The barber stifled his laughter 
and fought the desire to tell someone, yet the secret consumed him. One day, he walked outside the city 
and dug a hole in the ground. Plunging his head into the earth, the desperate barber whispered,
“Midas has ass’s ears.” Soon after, a clump of reeds sprang up in the spot where the barber 
had buried his words. When the wind blew, they carried the 
echoes of his whisper through the breeze: "Midas has ass’s ears." At the sound, donkeys in the fields raised
their heads in recognition and people chuckled to themselves 
at the follies of their king. With his golden touch and ass’s ears, 
Midas was not the most respected ruler. And where other leaders were honored 
through statues and temples, his people remembered him 
a little differently: in the depths of the glittering river 
and the rustle of the Phrygian wind.

Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Thor—son of Odin, god of thunder, 
and protector of mankind— struggled mightily against his greatest
challenge yet: opening a bag of food. It’d all started when Thor, along with his fleet-footed human servant
Thjalfi and Loki, the trickster god, set out on a journey to Jotunheim, 
land of the giants. Along the way, they’d met 
a giant named Skrymir, who offered to accompany them and
even carry their provisions in his bag. But when they made camp,
Skrymir dozed off and Thor couldn’t untie the sack. Frustrated and hungry, Thor tried 
to wake the giant three times by striking his head with his hammer 
Mjolnir as hard as he could. But each time, Skrymir thought 
it was only a falling acorn and went back to sleep. The next morning, Skrymir departed and eventually, the travelers reached 
a massive fortress called Utgard. Inside the long hall, 
they met the king of giants, Utgard-Loki, who greeted his guests with a challenge: each of them was to prove they were 
the best at some particular skill. Loki went first, declaring himself 
the world’s fastest eater. To test him, the king summoned 
his servant Logi and the two were placed at either 
end of a long trough stuffed with food. Loki ate his way inward 
with blinding speed. But when the contestants 
met in the center, Loki saw that his adversary 
had not only eaten just as much food, but also the bones 
and even the trough itself. Next was Thjalfi, who could 
outrun anything in the wild. The king summoned an ethereal-looking 
giant named Hugi, who outraced Thjalfi easily. But the boy would not give up 
and demanded a rematch. This time, Thjalfi finished close behind and the king admitted he’d never 
seen a human run so fast. Thjalfi tried a third time, 
running like his life depended on it, but Hugi was even faster than before. Finally, it was Thor’s turn. The king offered him a drinking horn, saying all his men 
could drain it in two gulps. Thor raised it to his lips and drank the surprisingly 
cold and salty mead in the longest gulp he could muster. Then a second. Then a third. But the level of the mead 
in the horn was only slightly lowered. To test Thor’s renowned strength, the king
offered a seemingly easy challenge: lift his pet cat off the ground. But this cat was as tall as Thor. Every time he tried to lift it, 
it arched its back, and straining with all his godly might, 
he only managed to lift one paw. Enraged, Thor demanded 
to wrestle any of the giants. The king summoned 
the giants’ old nursemaid, Elli. Though the woman looked frail, 
Thor couldn’t overpower her and grew weaker the longer he struggled,
until he was brought to one knee. The three companions prepared 
to leave, disappointed and humbled. But as the king escorted them out, he revealed that nothing in the castle 
had been what it seemed. Loki lost the eating contest because 
his opponent Logi was wildfire itself, devouring everything in its path. Thjalfi couldn’t outrun Hugi because
Hugi was the embodiment of thought, always faster than action. And even Thor couldn’t defeat Elli, 
or old age, which weakens everyone eventually. As for the other challenges, 
they had also been illusions. The drinking horn 
was filled with the ocean, and Thor had drained
enough to cause the tides. The cat was the serpent 
that encircles the world, and Thor’s efforts shifted the earth. And Skrymir had been 
Utgard-Loki in disguise, deflecting Thor’s hammer-blows to form
valleys in the surrounding mountains. The giant congratulated 
them on their prowess, which so frightened him he would 
never allow them in his land again. Thor and his companions failed 
the challenges presented to them. But in trying to achieve the impossible, they’d pushed themselves 
harder than ever before and changed the world 
in ways no one had expected.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Thor is known as _______.
Options: A. The protector of mankind, B. The trickster god, C. The god of thunder, D. The protector of mankind and the god of thunder, E. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was Thor's greatest challenge at the beginning of the story? Options: A. Opening a magical door, B. Lifting a massive boulder, C. Opening a bag of food, D. Crossing a treacherous river Correct Option: None
Question 2: Who accompanied Thor on his journey to Jotunheim? Options: A. Odin and Freya, B. Thjalfi and Loki, C. Heimdall and Aegir, D. Tyr and Baldur Correct Option: None
Question 3: What was the name of the giant who offered to carry Thor's provisions? Options: A. Skrymir, B. Utgard-Loki, C. Hugi, D. Elli Correct Option: None
Question 4: What was the name of the king of giants who greeted Thor and his companions? Options: A. Utgard-Loki, B. Skrymir, C. Odin, D. Thor Correct Option: None
Question 5: What was the challenge presented to Loki by the king of giants? Options: A. To outrun a giant, B. To lift a massive weight, C. To eat faster than the king's servant, D. To drink a magical potion Correct Option: None
Question 6: What was the true nature of Loki's opponent, Logi? Options: A. A giant with superhuman strength, B. A magical creature with the power of flight, C. Wildfire itself, D. A powerful sorcerer Correct Option: None
Question 7: What was the challenge presented to Thor by the king of giants to test his strength? Options: A. To lift a massive boulder, B. To wrestle a giant, C. To lift the king's pet cat, D. To break a magical chain Correct Option: None
Question 8: What was the true nature of the king's pet cat? Options: A. A magical creature with superhuman strength, B. A giant serpent that encircles the world, C. A powerful sorcerer in disguise, D. A mythical creature with the power of flight Correct Option: None
Question 9: What was the true nature of the drinking horn presented to Thor? Options: A. A magical horn that could grant wishes, B. A horn filled with a powerful potion, C. A horn filled with the ocean, D. A horn that could predict the future Correct Option: None

That they were weak and powerless against the giants, C. That even in failure, they could achieve great things and change the world, D. That they should never have traveled to Jotunheim Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Thor—son of Odin, god of thunder, 
and protector of mankind— struggled mightily against his greatest
challenge yet: opening a bag of food. It’d all started when Thor, along with his fleet-footed human servant
Thjalfi and Loki, the trickster god, set out on a journey to Jotunheim, 
land of the giants. Along the way, they’d met 
a giant named Skrymir, who offered to accompany them and
even carry their provisions in his bag. But when they made camp,
Skrymir dozed off and Thor couldn’t untie the sack. Frustrated and hungry, Thor tried 
to wake the giant three times by striking his head with his hammer 
Mjolnir as hard as he could. But each time, Skrymir thought 
it was only a falling acorn and went back to sleep. The next morning, Skrymir departed and eventually, the travelers reached 
a massive fortress called Utgard. Inside the long hall, 
they met the king of giants, Utgard-Loki, who greeted his guests with a challenge: each of them was to prove they were 
the best at some particular skill. Loki went first, declaring himself 
the world’s fastest eater. To test him, the king summoned 
his servant Logi and the two were placed at either 
end of a long trough stuffed with food. Loki ate his way inward 
with blinding speed. But when the contestants 
met in the center, Loki saw that his adversary 
had not only eaten just as much food, but also the bones 
and even the trough itself. Next was Thjalfi, who could 
outrun anything in the wild. The king summoned an ethereal-looking 
giant named Hugi, who outraced Thjalfi easily. But the boy would not give up 
and demanded a rematch. This time, Thjalfi finished close behind and the king admitted he’d never 
seen a human run so fast. Thjalfi tried a third time, 
running like his life depended on it, but Hugi was even faster than before. Finally, it was Thor’s turn. The king offered him a drinking horn, saying all his men 
could drain it in two gulps. Thor raised it to his lips and drank the surprisingly 
cold and salty mead in the longest gulp he could muster. Then a second. Then a third. But the level of the mead 
in the horn was only slightly lowered. To test Thor’s renowned strength, the king
offered a seemingly easy challenge: lift his pet cat off the ground. But this cat was as tall as Thor. Every time he tried to lift it, 
it arched its back, and straining with all his godly might, 
he only managed to lift one paw. Enraged, Thor demanded 
to wrestle any of the giants. The king summoned 
the giants’ old nursemaid, Elli. Though the woman looked frail, 
Thor couldn’t overpower her and grew weaker the longer he struggled,
until he was brought to one knee. The three companions prepared 
to leave, disappointed and humbled. But as the king escorted them out, he revealed that nothing in the castle 
had been what it seemed. Loki lost the eating contest because 
his opponent Logi was wildfire itself, devouring everything in its path. Thjalfi couldn’t outrun Hugi because
Hugi was the embodiment of thought, always faster than action. And even Thor couldn’t defeat Elli, 
or old age, which weakens everyone eventually. As for the other challenges, 
they had also been illusions. The drinking horn 
was filled with the ocean, and Thor had drained
enough to cause the tides. The cat was the serpent 
that encircles the world, and Thor’s efforts shifted the earth. And Skrymir had been 
Utgard-Loki in disguise, deflecting Thor’s hammer-blows to form
valleys in the surrounding mountains. The giant congratulated 
them on their prowess, which so frightened him he would 
never allow them in his land again. Thor and his companions failed 
the challenges presented to them. But in trying to achieve the impossible, they’d pushed themselves 
harder than ever before and changed the world 
in ways no one had expected.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Thor is known as _______.
Options: A. The protector of mankind, B. The trickster god, C. The god of thunder, D. The protector of mankind and the god of thunder, E. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was Thor's greatest challenge at the beginning of the story? Options: A. Opening a magical door, B. Lifting a massive boulder, C. Opening a bag of food, D. Crossing a treacherous river Correct Option: None

Question 6: What was the true nature of Loki's opponent, Logi? Options: A. A giant with superhuman strength, B. A magical creature with the power of flight, C. Wildfire itself, D. A powerful sorcerer Correct Option: None
Question 7: What was the challenge presented to Thor by the king of giants to test his strength? Options: A. To lift a massive boulder, B. To wrestle a giant, C. To lift the king's pet cat, D. To break a magical chain Correct Option: None
Question 8: What was the true nature of the king's pet cat? Options: A. A magical creature with superhuman strength, B. A giant serpent that encircles the world, C. A powerful sorcerer in disguise, D. A mythical creature with the power of flight Correct Option: None
Question 9: What was the true nature of the drinking horn presented to Thor? Options: A. A magical horn that could grant wishes, B. A horn filled with a powerful potion, C. A horn filled with the ocean, D. A horn that could predict the future Correct Option: None
Question 10: What was the lesson learned by Thor and his companions from their experiences in Jotunheim? Options: A. That they were invincible and could conquer any challenge, B. That they were weak and powerless against the giants, C. That even in failure, they could achieve great things and change the world, D. That they should never have traveled to Jotunheim Correct Option: None

never allow them in his land again. Thor and his companions failed

in ways no one had expected.

**Transcript**:
Thor—son of Odin, god of thunder, 
and protector of mankind— struggled mightily against his greatest
challenge yet: opening a bag of food. It’d all started when Thor, along with his fleet-footed human servant
Thjalfi and Loki, the trickster god, set out on a journey to Jotunheim, 
land of the giants. Along the way, they’d met 
a giant named Skrymir, who offered to accompany them and
even carry their provisions in his bag. But when they made camp,
Skrymir dozed off and Thor couldn’t untie the sack. Frustrated and hungry, Thor tried 
to wake the giant three times by striking his head with his hammer 
Mjolnir as hard as he could. But each time, Skrymir thought

a massive fortress called Utgard. Inside the long hall, 
they met the king of giants, Utgard-Loki, who greeted his guests with a challenge: each of them was to prove they were

could drain it in two gulps. Thor raised it to his lips and drank the surprisingly

he only managed to lift one paw. Enraged, Thor demanded 
to wrestle any of the giants. The king summoned

until he was brought to one knee. The three companions prepared

had been what it seemed. Loki lost the eating contest because

in ways no one had expected.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 6
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Thor—son of Odin, god of thunder, 
and protector of mankind— struggled mightily against his greatest
challenge yet: opening a bag of food. It’d all started when Thor, along with his fleet-footed human servant
Thjalfi and Loki, the trickster god, set out on a journey to Jotunheim, 
land of the giants. Along the way, they’d met 
a giant named Skrymir, who offered to accompany them and
even carry their provisions in his bag. But when they made camp,
Skrymir dozed off and Thor couldn’t untie the sack. Frustrated and hungry, Thor tried 
to wake the giant three times by striking his head with his hammer 
Mjolnir as hard as he could. But each time, Skrymir thought 
it was only a falling acorn and went back to sleep. The next morning, Skrymir departed and eventually, the travelers reached 
a massive fortress called Utgard. Inside the long hall, 
they met the king of giants, Utgard-Loki, who greeted his guests with a challenge: each of them was to prove they were 
the best at some particular skill. Loki went first, declaring himself 
the world’s fastest eater. To test him, the king summoned 
his servant Logi and the two were placed at either 
end of a long trough stuffed with food. Loki ate his way inward 
with blinding speed. But when the contestants 
met in the center, Loki saw that his adversary 
had not only eaten just as much food, but also the bones 
and even the trough itself. Next was Thjalfi, who could 
outrun anything in the wild. The king summoned an ethereal-looking 
giant named Hugi, who outraced Thjalfi easily. But the boy would not give up 
and demanded a rematch. This time, Thjalfi finished close behind and the king admitted he’d never 
seen a human run so fast. Thjalfi tried a third time, 
running like his life depended on it, but Hugi was even faster than before. Finally, it was Thor’s turn. The king offered him a drinking horn, saying all his men 
could drain it in two gulps. Thor raised it to his lips and drank the surprisingly 
cold and salty mead in the longest gulp he could muster. Then a second. Then a third. But the level of the mead 
in the horn was only slightly lowered. To test Thor’s renowned strength, the king
offered a seemingly easy challenge: lift his pet cat off the ground. But this cat was as tall as Thor. Every time he tried to lift it, 
it arched its back, and straining with all his godly might, 
he only managed to lift one paw. Enraged, Thor demanded 
to wrestle any of the giants. The king summoned 
the giants’ old nursemaid, Elli. Though the woman looked frail, 
Thor couldn’t overpower her and grew weaker the longer he struggled,
until he was brought to one knee. The three companions prepared 
to leave, disappointed and humbled. But as the king escorted them out, he revealed that nothing in the castle 
had been what it seemed. Loki lost the eating contest because 
his opponent Logi was wildfire itself, devouring everything in its path. Thjalfi couldn’t outrun Hugi because
Hugi was the embodiment of thought, always faster than action. And even Thor couldn’t defeat Elli, 
or old age, which weakens everyone eventually. As for the other challenges, 
they had also been illusions. The drinking horn 
was filled with the ocean, and Thor had drained
enough to cause the tides. The cat was the serpent 
that encircles the world, and Thor’s efforts shifted the earth. And Skrymir had been 
Utgard-Loki in disguise, deflecting Thor’s hammer-blows to form
valleys in the surrounding mountains. The giant congratulated 
them on their prowess, which so frightened him he would 
never allow them in his land again. Thor and his companions failed 
the challenges presented to them. But in trying to achieve the impossible, they’d pushed themselves 
harder than ever before and changed the world 
in ways no one had expected.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The drinking horn was filled with the ocean. Thor drank enough of it to cause _______.
Options: A. A tsunami, B. The tides, C. A drought, D. Boats to capsize
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It was the Western Hemisphere’s 
largest empire ever, with a population 
of nearly 10 million subjects. Over an area of more 
than 900,000 square kilometers, its people built massive 
administrative centers, temples, and extensive road 
and canal systems. They did so in an inhospitable, 
extreme terrain, all without the use of wheels, 
horses, iron, or even written language. Yet within 100 years of its rise 
in the fifteenth century, the Inca Empire would be no more. According to legend, the ancestors of the Inca rulers 
were created by the sun god Inti, and they emerged
from a cave called Tambo Toco. Leading four brothers 
and four sisters was Ayar Manco, who carried a golden staff 
with instructions to find the place where 
it would sink into the ground, showing fertile soil. After many adventures 
and extensive searching, Ayar Manco and his siblings 
reached the Cuzco Valley, where the staff pierced the ground. After fighting off the fierce 
local native population, they founded their capital, and Ayar Manco became Manco Capac, 
the first Sapa Inca, or king of the Incas. Archaeological evidence suggests that the Incas first settled 
in this valley around 1200 CE. They remained a small kingdom until 1438, when they were nearly overrun 
by the neighboring Chanka tribe. The Inca king at this time, Viracocha, 
and his designated heir fled in fear, but one of his other sons remained and successfully rallied 
the city’s defenses. For his military skill, he became 
the ninth Inca ruler, assuming the name of Pachacuti, 
or "Cataclysm." Pachacuti expanded Inca rule 
throughout the Andes mountains, transforming the kingdom into 
an empire through extensive reforms. The empire’s territory was reorganized 
as Tahuantinsuyu, or "four quarters," with four divisions ruled 
by governors reporting to the king. Although the Inca had no writing, they used a complex system 
of knotted strings called quipu to record numbers 
and perhaps other information. A decimal-based bureaucracy 
enabled systematic and efficient taxation 
of the empire’s subjects. In return, the empire provided security, 
infrastructure, and sustenance, with great storehouses containing 
necessities to be used when needed. Great terraces and irrigation works 
were built and various crops were grown in 
at different altitudes to be transported all over the empire. And it was during Pachacuti’s reign that the famous estate 
of Machu Picchu was constructed. Pachacuti’s son Topa Inca continued 
the empire’s military expansion, and he eventually became ruler
in 1471 CE. By the end of his reign, the empire 
covered much of western South America. Topa’s son Huayna Capac 
succeeded him in 1493. But the new ruler’s distant military 
campaigns strained the social fabric. And in 1524, Huayna Capac 
was stricken by fever. Spanish conquistadors had arrived 
in the Caribbean some time before, bringing diseases to which 
the native peoples had no resistance. Millions died in the outbreak, including Huayna Capac
and his designated heir. The vacant throne ignited a civil war
between two of the surviving brothers, Atahualpa and Huascar, greatly weakening the empire. In 1532, after finally winning 
the Inca civil war, Atahualpa and his army 
encountered the European invaders. Although greatly outnumbered, Francisco Pizarro 
and his small group of conquistadors stunned the king’s much larger force 
with guns and horses, neither of which they had seen before. Atahualpa was taken captive 
and killed about a year later. The Spanish conquerors 
were awed by the capital of Cuzco. Pizarro described it as so beautiful that
“it would be remarkable even in Spain.” Though the capital had fallen and the native population had been
destroyed by civil war and disease, some Incas fell back to 
a new capital at Vilcabamba and resisted for the next 40 years. But by 1572, the Spaniards had destroyed 
all remaining resistance along with much of the Incas’ physical 
and cultural legacy. Thus, the great Inca empire fell 
even faster than it had risen.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Who was the first Inca ruler?
Options: A. Pachacuti, B. Topa Inca, C. Atahualpa, D. Manco Capac
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the approximate population of the Inca Empire at its peak? Options: A. 1 million, B. 5 million, C. 10 million, D. 20 million Correct Option: None
Question 2: What was the name of the sun god who, according to legend, created the ancestors of the Inca rulers? Options: A. Inti, B. Viracocha, C. Pachacuti, D. Ayar Manco Correct Option: None
Question 3: What was the name of the system used by the Incas to record numbers and other information? Options: A. Quipu, B. Tahuantinsuyu, C. Machu Picchu, D. Inca script Correct Option: None
Question 4: What was the name of the Inca king who transformed the kingdom into an empire through extensive reforms? Options: A. Viracocha, B. Pachacuti, C. Topa Inca, D. Huayna Capac Correct Option: None
Question 5: What was the name of the famous estate constructed during Pachacuti's reign? Options: A. Machu Picchu, B. Cuzco, C. Vilcabamba, D. Tambo Toco Correct Option: None
Question 6: What was the main reason for the decline of the Inca Empire? Options: A. Civil war between Atahualpa and Huascar, B. Spanish conquest, C. Disease brought by European invaders, D. All of the above Correct Option: None
Question 7: Who was the Spanish conquistador who led the small group that defeated the Inca army? Options: A. Francisco Pizarro, B. Hernán Cortés, C. Vasco Núñez de Balboa, D. Juan Sebastián Elcano Correct Option: None
Question 8: What was the name of the new capital where some Incas fell back to resist the Spanish conquerors? Options: A. Vilcabamba, B. Cuzco, C. Machu Picchu, D. Tambo Toco Correct Option: None
Question 9: How long did the Incas resist the Spanish conquerors from their new capital? Options: A. 10 years, B. 20 years, C. 30 years, D. 40 years Correct Option: None
Question 10: In what year did the Spanish conquerors finally destroy all remaining resistance from the Incas? Options: A. 1532, B. 1550, C. 1560, D. 1572 Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ. However, based on the content and intent of the questions, the most similar generated MCQ would be Question 4: What was the name of the Inca king who transformed the kingdom into an empire through extensive reforms? Options: A. Viracocha, B. Pachacuti, C. Topa Inca, D. Huayna Capac.

Although this question does not ask about the first Inca ruler, it does mention Inca kings, which is related to the ground truth MCQ. However, a more suitable generated MCQ would be one that directly asks about the first Inca ruler.

Since none of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ, I will not provide an index. Instead, I suggest creating a new generated MCQ that directly asks about the first Inca ruler, such as:

Question: Who was the first ruler of the Inca Empire?
Options: A. Pachacuti, B. Topa Inca, C. Atahualpa, D. Manco Capac

This new generated MCQ would be a more suitable match for the ground truth MCQ.

Question 7: Who was the Spanish conquistador who led the small group that defeated the Inca army? Options: A. Francisco Pizarro, B. Hernán Cortés, C. Vasco Núñez de Balboa, D. Juan Sebastián Elcano Correct Option: None
Question 8: What was the name of the new capital where some Incas fell back to resist the Spanish conquerors? Options: A. Vilcabamba, B. Cuzco, C. Machu Picchu, D. Tambo Toco Correct Option: None
Question 9: How long did the Incas resist the Spanish conquerors from their new capital? Options: A. 10 years, B. 20 years, C. 30 years, D. 40 years Correct Option: None
Question 10: In what year did the Spanish conquerors finally destroy all remaining resistance from the Incas? Options: A. 1532, B. 1550, C. 1560, D. 1572 Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ. However, based on the information provided in the transcript, the closest match would be a question that asks about the organization or structure of the Inca Empire.

The closest match is not explicitly present, but Question 3 mentions "Tahuantinsuyu," which is related to the organization of the empire. According to the transcript, "The empire's territory was reorganized as Tahuantinsuyu, or 'four quarters,' with four divisions ruled by governors reporting to the king."

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It was the Western Hemisphere’s 
largest empire ever, with a population 
of nearly 10 million subjects. Over an area of more 
than 900,000 square kilometers, its people built massive 
administrative centers, temples, and extensive road 
and canal systems. They did so in an inhospitable, 
extreme terrain, all without the use of wheels, 
horses, iron, or even written language. Yet within 100 years of its rise 
in the fifteenth century, the Inca Empire would be no more. According to legend, the ancestors of the Inca rulers 
were created by the sun god Inti, and they emerged
from a cave called Tambo Toco. Leading four brothers 
and four sisters was Ayar Manco, who carried a golden staff 
with instructions to find the place where 
it would sink into the ground, showing fertile soil. After many adventures 
and extensive searching, Ayar Manco and his siblings 
reached the Cuzco Valley, where the staff pierced the ground. After fighting off the fierce 
local native population, they founded their capital, and Ayar Manco became Manco Capac, 
the first Sapa Inca, or king of the Incas. Archaeological evidence suggests that the Incas first settled 
in this valley around 1200 CE. They remained a small kingdom until 1438, when they were nearly overrun 
by the neighboring Chanka tribe. The Inca king at this time, Viracocha, 
and his designated heir fled in fear, but one of his other sons remained and successfully rallied 
the city’s defenses. For his military skill, he became 
the ninth Inca ruler, assuming the name of Pachacuti, 
or "Cataclysm." Pachacuti expanded Inca rule 
throughout the Andes mountains, transforming the kingdom into 
an empire through extensive reforms. The empire’s territory was reorganized 
as Tahuantinsuyu, or "four quarters," with four divisions ruled 
by governors reporting to the king. Although the Inca had no writing, they used a complex system 
of knotted strings called quipu to record numbers 
and perhaps other information. A decimal-based bureaucracy 
enabled systematic and efficient taxation 
of the empire’s subjects. In return, the empire provided security, 
infrastructure, and sustenance, with great storehouses containing 
necessities to be used when needed. Great terraces and irrigation works 
were built and various crops were grown in 
at different altitudes to be transported all over the empire. And it was during Pachacuti’s reign that the famous estate 
of Machu Picchu was constructed. Pachacuti’s son Topa Inca continued 
the empire’s military expansion, and he eventually became ruler
in 1471 CE. By the end of his reign, the empire 
covered much of western South America. Topa’s son Huayna Capac 
succeeded him in 1493. But the new ruler’s distant military 
campaigns strained the social fabric. And in 1524, Huayna Capac 
was stricken by fever. Spanish conquistadors had arrived 
in the Caribbean some time before, bringing diseases to which 
the native peoples had no resistance. Millions died in the outbreak, including Huayna Capac
and his designated heir. The vacant throne ignited a civil war
between two of the surviving brothers, Atahualpa and Huascar, greatly weakening the empire. In 1532, after finally winning 
the Inca civil war, Atahualpa and his army 
encountered the European invaders. Although greatly outnumbered, Francisco Pizarro 
and his small group of conquistadors stunned the king’s much larger force 
with guns and horses, neither of which they had seen before. Atahualpa was taken captive 
and killed about a year later. The Spanish conquerors 
were awed by the capital of Cuzco. Pizarro described it as so beautiful that
“it would be remarkable even in Spain.” Though the capital had fallen and the native population had been
destroyed by civil war and disease, some Incas fell back to 
a new capital at Vilcabamba and resisted for the next 40 years. But by 1572, the Spaniards had destroyed 
all remaining resistance along with much of the Incas’ physical 
and cultural legacy. Thus, the great Inca empire fell 
even faster than it had risen.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which two Incas engaged in civil war just before the arrival of the Spaniards?
Options: A. Atahualpa and Huascar, B. Topa Inca and Pachacuti, C. Manco Capac and Viracocha Inca, D. Huayna Capac and Atahualpa
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the approximate population of the Inca Empire at its peak? Options: A. 1 million, B. 5 million, C. 10 million, D. 20 million Correct Option: None
Question 2: What was the name of the sun god who, according to legend, created the ancestors of the Inca rulers? Options: A. Inti, B. Viracocha, C. Pachacuti, D. Ayar Manco Correct Option: None
Question 3: What was the name of the system used by the Incas to record numbers and other information? Options: A. Quipu, B. Tahuantinsuyu, C. Machu Picchu, D. Inca script Correct Option: None
Question 4: What was the name of the Inca king who transformed the kingdom into an empire through extensive reforms? Options: A. Viracocha, B. Pachacuti, C. Topa Inca, D. Huayna Capac Correct Option: None
Question 5: What was the name of the famous estate constructed during Pachacuti's reign? Options: A. Machu Picchu, B. Cuzco, C. Vilcabamba, D. Tambo Toco Correct Option: None
Question 6: What was the main reason for the decline of the Inca Empire? Options: A. Civil war between Atahualpa and Huascar, B. Spanish conquest, C. Disease brought by European invaders, D. All of the above Correct Option: None
Question 7: Who was the Spanish conquistador who led the small group that defeated the Inca army? Options: A. Francisco Pizarro, B. Hernán Cortés, C. Vasco Núñez de Balboa, D. Juan Sebastián Elcano Correct Option: None
Question 8: What was the name of the new capital where some Incas fell back to resist the Spanish conquerors? Options: A. Vilcabamba, B. Cuzco, C. Machu Picchu, D. Tambo Toco Correct Option: None
Question 9: How long did the Incas resist the Spanish conquerors from their new capital? Options: A. 10 years, B. 20 years, C. 30 years, D. 40 years Correct Option: None
Question 10: In what year did the Spanish conquerors finally destroy all remaining resistance from the Incas? Options: A. 1532, B. 1550, C. 1560, D. 1572 Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 6: What was the main reason for the decline of the Inca Empire? Options: A. Civil war between Atahualpa and Huascar, B. Spanish conquest, C. Disease brought by European invaders, D. All of the above.

Although the question is not an exact match, option A in Question 6 mentions the civil war between Atahualpa and Huascar, which is the same as the ground truth MCQ. However, it's worth noting that the question intent is slightly different, as the ground truth MCQ specifically asks about the two Incas who engaged in civil war, while Question 6 asks about the main reason for the decline of the Inca Empire.

**Transcript**:
It was the Western Hemisphere’s 
largest empire ever, with a population 
of nearly 10 million subjects. Over an area of more 
than 900,000 square kilometers, its people built massive 
administrative centers, temples, and extensive road 
and canal systems. They did so in an inhospitable, 
extreme terrain, all without the use of wheels, 
horses, iron, or even written language. Yet within 100 years of its rise 
in the fifteenth century, the Inca Empire would be no more. According to legend, the ancestors of the Inca rulers 
were created by the sun god Inti, and they emerged
from a cave called Tambo Toco. Leading four brothers 
and four sisters was Ayar Manco, who carried a golden staff 
with instructions to find the place where 
it would sink into the ground, showing fertile soil. After many adventures 
and extensive searching, Ayar Manco and his siblings 
reached the Cuzco Valley, where the staff pierced the ground. After fighting off the fierce

the first Sapa Inca, or king of the Incas. Archaeological evidence suggests that the Incas first settled 
in this valley around 1200 CE. They remained a small kingdom until 1438, when they were nearly overrun

the ninth Inca ruler, assuming the name of Pachacuti, 
or "Cataclysm." Pachacuti expanded Inca rule

an empire through extensive reforms. The empire’s territory was reorganized

by governors reporting to the king. Although the Inca had no writing, they used a complex system 
of knotted strings called quipu to record numbers 
and perhaps other information. A decimal-based bureaucracy 
enabled systematic and efficient taxation 
of the empire’s subjects. In return, the empire provided security, 
infrastructure, and sustenance, with great storehouses containing 
necessities to be used when needed. Great terraces and irrigation works 
were built and various crops were grown in 
at different altitudes to be transported all over the empire. And it was during Pachacuti’s reign that the famous estate 
of Machu Picchu was constructed. Pachacuti’s son Topa Inca continued 
the empire’s military expansion, and he eventually became ruler
in 1471 CE. By the end of his reign, the empire 
covered much of western South America. Topa’s son Huayna Capac 
succeeded him in 1493. But the new ruler’s distant military 
campaigns strained the social fabric. And in 1524, Huayna Capac 
was stricken by fever. Spanish conquistadors had arrived 
in the Caribbean some time before, bringing diseases to which 
the native peoples had no resistance. Millions died in the outbreak, including Huayna Capac
and his designated heir. The vacant throne ignited a civil war
between two of the surviving brothers, Atahualpa and Huascar, greatly weakening the empire. In 1532, after finally winning 
the Inca civil war, Atahualpa and his army 
encountered the European invaders. Although greatly outnumbered, Francisco Pizarro 
and his small group of conquistadors stunned the king’s much larger force 
with guns and horses, neither of which they had seen before. Atahualpa was taken captive 
and killed about a year later. The Spanish conquerors 
were awed by the capital of Cuzco. Pizarro described it as so beautiful that
“it would be remarkable even in Spain.” Though the capital had fallen and the native population had been
destroyed by civil war and disease, some Incas fell back to 
a new capital at Vilcabamba and resisted for the next 40 years. But by 1572, the Spaniards had destroyed 
all remaining resistance along with much of the Incas’ physical 
and cultural legacy. Thus, the great Inca empire fell 
even faster than it had risen.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 13, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
From sailors who were turned into pigs, nymphs that sprouted into trees, and a gaze that converted 
the beholder to stone, Greek mythology brims with shape-shifters. The powerful gods usually changed 
their own forms at will, but for mortals, the mutations 
were often unwanted. One such unnerving transformation 
befell the spinner Arachne. Arachne was the daughter 
of a tradesman who spent his days dying cloth 
the deepest shades of purple. She had a flair for spinning 
the finest threads, weaving them into flowing fabric, and creating magnificent tapestries. People flocked to watch her hands 
flying across her loom, as if thread sprung directly 
from her fingertips. But as praise for her work grew, 
so did her pride. Arachne could often be heard 
boasting about her skills, declaring that her talent surpassed 
anyone else’s—mortal or divine. She refused to see weaving 
as a gift from the gods. Rather, she flaunted it 
as her own personal genius. Unfortunately, the goddess of wisdom 
and crafts, Athena, overheard Arachne 
making these claims. Planning to teach 
the ungrateful girl a lesson, Athena disguised herself as an old woman
and stole amongst the mortals. She berated Arachne in public— how dare the weaver claim
herself greater than the gods? But Arachne only laughed, 
barely looking up from her loom. Provoked, the old woman threw off
her cloak to reveal her true form. If Arachne insisted on defaming the gods, Athena would challenge her 
to a contest directly. Masking her shock at the appearance 
of the grey-eyed goddess, Arachne accepted the challenge. Athena drew up her own glittering loom 
as a great crowd gathered to watch. The weavers began, 
eyes fixed and shuttles blurring. Athena conjured 
wisps of cloud from above and slender threads of grass 
from below in a spectacle of strength. She wove tremendous scenes 
that showed the power of the gods: Poseidon riding the waves, Zeus firing thunderbolts, and Apollo hurtling across the sky. In Athena’s splendid tapestry, 
the glory of the gods dwarfed mortal life. But Arachne had no interest 
in boosting godly egos. Her tapestry showed the gods
abusing their power: squabbling amongst themselves, drinking and bragging, and meddling in the lives of mortals. She represented Zeus as a philanderer,
transfiguring himself to ensnare women: a swan for Leda, a bull for Europa, a shower of gold for Danae. Arachne then turned
to the misdemeanors of other gods, from Pluto’s abduction of Persephone to Bacchus’s wild pursuit of Erigone. Even though she cast the gods 
in the most unflattering light, Arachne’s work shone 
with her dazzling skill. Her tapestry was almost alive, filled with movement 
and lustrous colors that winked triumphantly. When Athena saw Arachne's undeniably
better and flagrantly subversive work, she flew into a rage 
and turned on the human weaver. Arachne’s glee dimmed as she felt her body
shrinking and contorting. Her fingers waved wildly 
as her arms stuck to her sides, and black hair
sprouted all over her body. The goddess left Arachne with a single 
spool of thread unfurling from her belly, a slim reminder of her human talent. For challenging the assumption
that the gods were untouchable, Athena had shrunk her adversary 
into the first spider. To this day, Arachne and her children spin
out her penance— or is it undaunted persistence?— in the shadows of giants.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Arachne was ______.
Options: A. A noblewoman, B. An apprentice, C. A slave, D. A self-taught weaver
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who was Arachne, and what was she known for? Options: A. A goddess known for her wisdom, B. A mortal known for her exceptional spinning skills, C. A nymph known for her singing voice, D. A sailor known for his bravery Correct Option: None
Question 2: Why did Athena disguise herself as an old woman and confront Arachne? Options: A. To praise Arachne's spinning skills, B. To teach Arachne a lesson for her pride and claims of being better than the gods, C. To invite Arachne to a weaving contest, D. To sell Arachne some rare threads Correct Option: None
Question 3: What was the subject of Athena's tapestry in the weaving contest? Options: A. The lives of mortals, B. The power and glory of the gods, C. The beauty of nature, D. The history of Greece Correct Option: None
Question 4: How did Arachne's tapestry differ from Athena's? Options: A. Arachne's tapestry showed the gods in a more positive light, B. Arachne's tapestry was less colorful and less detailed, C. Arachne's tapestry showed the gods abusing their power, D. Arachne's tapestry was smaller and less impressive Correct Option: None
Question 5: Why did Athena turn Arachne into a spider? Options: A. As a reward for her exceptional spinning skills, B. As a punishment for challenging the assumption that the gods were untouchable, C. As a way to make her a more skilled weaver, D. As a joke to play on the other gods Correct Option: None
Question 6: What was left with Arachne after she was turned into a spider? Options: A. A loom and a set of threads, B. A single spool of thread unfurling from her belly, C. A pair of scissors and a needle, D. A bag of wool and a spinning wheel Correct Option: None
Question 7: What was Arachne's attitude towards her spinning skills? Options: A. She saw them as a gift from the gods, B. She saw them as a result of her own hard work and dedication, C. She saw them as a way to impress the gods, D. She saw them as a way to make money Correct Option: None
Question 8: How did the crowd react to the weaving contest between Athena and Arachne? Options: A. They were bored and unimpressed, B. They were divided in their opinion, with some supporting Athena and others supporting Arachne, C. They were amazed by the skill and creativity of both weavers, D. They were not present, as the contest was held in private Correct Option: None
Question 9: What was the theme of Arachne's tapestry? Options: A. The power and glory of the gods, B. The lives and struggles of mortals, C. The abuse of power by the gods, D. The beauty and wonder of nature Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the symbolic meaning of Arachne's transformation into a spider? Options: A. It represents the punishment for challenging the gods, B. It represents the reward for exceptional spinning skills, C. It represents the transformation of a mortal into a goddess, D. It represents the persistence and creativity of an artist Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 7: What was Arachne's attitude towards her spinning skills? 

This question is similar in intent and content to the ground truth MCQ, which asks about Arachne's identity and implies her attitude towards her skills. Although the options are not identical, they both relate to Arachne's perspective on her abilities. The correct option in the ground truth MCQ, "A self-taught weaver," suggests that Arachne takes pride in her skills and sees them as a result of her own efforts, which aligns with option B in Question 7.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 7

It represents the persistence and creativity of an artist Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

If I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ, I would say that none of the generated MCQs are similar to the ground truth MCQ. But if you insist on an answer, I would say that Question 7 is the closest in terms of mentioning Athena's domain (wisdom and crafts) indirectly through the context of Arachne's skills.

However, I must emphasize that this is a very weak connection, and it's not a good match.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 13, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
From sailors who were turned into pigs, nymphs that sprouted into trees, and a gaze that converted 
the beholder to stone, Greek mythology brims with shape-shifters. The powerful gods usually changed 
their own forms at will, but for mortals, the mutations 
were often unwanted. One such unnerving transformation 
befell the spinner Arachne. Arachne was the daughter 
of a tradesman who spent his days dying cloth 
the deepest shades of purple. She had a flair for spinning 
the finest threads, weaving them into flowing fabric, and creating magnificent tapestries. People flocked to watch her hands 
flying across her loom, as if thread sprung directly 
from her fingertips. But as praise for her work grew, 
so did her pride. Arachne could often be heard 
boasting about her skills, declaring that her talent surpassed 
anyone else’s—mortal or divine. She refused to see weaving 
as a gift from the gods. Rather, she flaunted it 
as her own personal genius. Unfortunately, the goddess of wisdom 
and crafts, Athena, overheard Arachne 
making these claims. Planning to teach 
the ungrateful girl a lesson, Athena disguised herself as an old woman
and stole amongst the mortals. She berated Arachne in public— how dare the weaver claim
herself greater than the gods? But Arachne only laughed, 
barely looking up from her loom. Provoked, the old woman threw off
her cloak to reveal her true form. If Arachne insisted on defaming the gods, Athena would challenge her 
to a contest directly. Masking her shock at the appearance 
of the grey-eyed goddess, Arachne accepted the challenge. Athena drew up her own glittering loom 
as a great crowd gathered to watch. The weavers began, 
eyes fixed and shuttles blurring. Athena conjured 
wisps of cloud from above and slender threads of grass 
from below in a spectacle of strength. She wove tremendous scenes 
that showed the power of the gods: Poseidon riding the waves, Zeus firing thunderbolts, and Apollo hurtling across the sky. In Athena’s splendid tapestry, 
the glory of the gods dwarfed mortal life. But Arachne had no interest 
in boosting godly egos. Her tapestry showed the gods
abusing their power: squabbling amongst themselves, drinking and bragging, and meddling in the lives of mortals. She represented Zeus as a philanderer,
transfiguring himself to ensnare women: a swan for Leda, a bull for Europa, a shower of gold for Danae. Arachne then turned
to the misdemeanors of other gods, from Pluto’s abduction of Persephone to Bacchus’s wild pursuit of Erigone. Even though she cast the gods 
in the most unflattering light, Arachne’s work shone 
with her dazzling skill. Her tapestry was almost alive, filled with movement 
and lustrous colors that winked triumphantly. When Athena saw Arachne's undeniably
better and flagrantly subversive work, she flew into a rage 
and turned on the human weaver. Arachne’s glee dimmed as she felt her body
shrinking and contorting. Her fingers waved wildly 
as her arms stuck to her sides, and black hair
sprouted all over her body. The goddess left Arachne with a single 
spool of thread unfurling from her belly, a slim reminder of her human talent. For challenging the assumption
that the gods were untouchable, Athena had shrunk her adversary 
into the first spider. To this day, Arachne and her children spin
out her penance— or is it undaunted persistence?— in the shadows of giants.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Athena disguised herself and stole amongst the mortals in order to ______.
Options: A. Admire Arachne’s work anonymously, B. Hear Arachne’s boasting for herself, C. See if Arachne was a better weaver than she was, D. Steal Arachne’s talent for herself, E. See if Arachne was a better weaver than she was and steal Arachne’s talent for herself
Correct Option: E

Arachne's tapestry showed the gods abusing their power, D. Arachne's tapestry was smaller and less impressive Correct Option: None
Question 5: Why did Athena turn Arachne into a spider? Options: A. As a reward for her exceptional spinning skills, B. As a punishment for challenging the assumption that the gods were untouchable, C. As a way to make her a more skilled weaver, D. As a joke to play on the other gods Correct Option: None
Question 6: What was left with Arachne after she was turned into a spider? Options: A. A loom and a set of threads, B. A single spool of thread unfurling from her belly, C. A pair of scissors and a needle, D. A bag of wool and a spinning wheel Correct Option: None
Question 7: What was Arachne's attitude towards her spinning skills? Options: A. She saw them as a gift from the gods, B. She saw them as a result of her own hard work and dedication, C. She saw them as a way to impress the gods, D. She saw them as a way to make money Correct Option: None
Question 8: How did the crowd react to the weaving contest between Athena and Arachne? Options: A. They were bored and unimpressed, B. They were divided in their opinion, with some supporting Athena and others supporting Arachne, C. They were amazed by the skill and creativity of both weavers, D. They were not present, as the contest was held in private Correct Option: None
Question 9: What was the theme of Arachne's tapestry? Options: A. The power and glory of the gods, B. The lives and struggles of mortals, C. The abuse of power by the gods, D. The beauty and wonder of nature Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the symbolic meaning of Arachne's transformation into a spider? Options: A. It represents the punishment for challenging the gods, B. It represents the reward for exceptional spinning skills, C. It represents the transformation of a mortal into a goddess, D. It represents the persistence and creativity of an artist Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

Although the options do not exactly match, the intent and content of the question are similar. The ground truth MCQ asks why Athena disguised herself and stole amongst the mortals, and the correct option is to see if Arachne was a better weaver than she was and steal Arachne's talent for herself, but more accurately, it was to teach Arachne a lesson for her pride and claims of being better than the gods. 

Question 2 asks why Athena disguised herself as an old woman and confronted Arachne, and option B states that it was to teach Arachne a lesson for her pride and claims of being better than the gods, which aligns with the actual reason in the transcript. 

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 2.

**Transcript**:
From sailors who were turned into pigs, nymphs that sprouted into trees, and a gaze that converted 
the beholder to stone, Greek mythology brims with shape-shifters. The powerful gods usually changed 
their own forms at will, but for mortals, the mutations 
were often unwanted. One such unnerving transformation 
befell the spinner Arachne. Arachne was the daughter 
of a tradesman who spent his days dying cloth 
the deepest shades of purple. She had a flair for spinning 
the finest threads, weaving them into flowing fabric, and creating magnificent tapestries. People flocked to watch her hands 
flying across her loom, as if thread sprung directly 
from her fingertips. But as praise for her work grew, 
so did her pride. Arachne could often be heard 
boasting about her skills, declaring that her talent surpassed 
anyone else’s—mortal or divine. She refused to see weaving 
as a gift from the gods. Rather, she flaunted it 
as her own personal genius. Unfortunately, the goddess of wisdom 
and crafts, Athena, overheard Arachne 
making these claims. Planning to teach 
the ungrateful girl a lesson, Athena disguised herself as an old woman
and stole amongst the mortals. She berated Arachne in public— how dare the weaver claim
herself greater than the gods? But Arachne only laughed, 
barely looking up from her loom. Provoked, the old woman threw off
her cloak to reveal her true form. If Arachne insisted on defaming the gods, Athena would challenge her 
to a contest directly. Masking her shock at the appearance 
of the grey-eyed goddess, Arachne accepted the challenge. Athena drew up her own glittering loom 
as a great crowd gathered to watch. The weavers began, 
eyes fixed and shuttles blurring. Athena conjured 
wisps of cloud from above and slender threads of grass 
from below in a spectacle of strength. She wove tremendous scenes 
that showed the power of the gods: Poseidon riding the waves, Zeus firing thunderbolts, and Apollo hurtling across the sky. In Athena’s splendid tapestry, 
the glory of the gods dwarfed mortal life. But Arachne had no interest 
in boosting godly egos. Her tapestry showed the gods
abusing their power: squabbling amongst themselves, drinking and bragging, and meddling in the lives of mortals. She represented Zeus as a philanderer,
transfiguring himself to ensnare women: a swan for Leda, a bull for Europa, a shower of gold for Danae. Arachne then turned
to the misdemeanors of other gods, from Pluto’s abduction of Persephone to Bacchus’s wild pursuit of Erigone. Even though she cast the gods 
in the most unflattering light, Arachne’s work shone 
with her dazzling skill. Her tapestry was almost alive, filled with movement 
and lustrous colors that winked triumphantly. When Athena saw Arachne's undeniably
better and flagrantly subversive work, she flew into a rage 
and turned on the human weaver. Arachne’s glee dimmed as she felt her body
shrinking and contorting. Her fingers waved wildly 
as her arms stuck to her sides, and black hair
sprouted all over her body. The goddess left Arachne with a single 
spool of thread unfurling from her belly, a slim reminder of her human talent. For challenging the assumption
that the gods were untouchable, Athena had shrunk her adversary 
into the first spider. To this day, Arachne and her children spin
out her penance— or is it undaunted persistence?— in the shadows of giants.

Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 14, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
You may take them for granted, 
but your teeth are a marvel. They break up all your food 
over the course of your life, while being strong enough
to withstand breakage themselves. And they’re formed using 
only the raw materials from the food they grind down 
in the first place. What’s behind their impressive strength? Teeth rely on an ingenious structure 
that makes them both hard and tough. Hardness can be thought of as the ability 
to resist a crack from starting, while toughness is what stops 
the crack from spreading Very few materials have both properties. For instance, glass is hard but not tough, while leather is tough but not hard. Teeth manage both by having two layers: a hard external cap of enamel, made up
almost entirely of a calcium phosphate, and beneath it, 
a tougher layer of dentin, partly formed from organic fibers 
that make it flexible. This amazing structure is created 
by two types of cells: ameloblasts that secrete enamel and odontoblasts that secrete dentin. As they form teeth, 
odontoblasts move inward, while ameloblasts move out 
and slough off when they hit the surface. For enamel, this process produces long, 
thin strands, each about 60 nanometers in diameter. That’s one one-thousandth 
the width of a human hair. Those are bundled into rods, 
packed together, tens of thousands per square millimeter, to form the shield-like enamel layer. Once this process is finished, 
your enamel can’t repair itself again because all the cells 
that make it are lost, so we’re lucky that enamel 
can’t be easily destroyed. Odontoblasts use a more complex process,
but unlike ameloblasts, they stick around, continuing to secrete dentin 
throughout your life. Despite the differences in teeth 
across the mammalian order, the underlying process of tooth growth 
is the same whether it’s for lions, kangaroos, elephants, or us. What changes is how nature sculpts 
the shape of the tooth, altering the folding and growth patterns to suit the distinct diets 
of different species. Cows have flat molar teeth with parallel 
ridges for grinding tough grasses. Cats have sharp crested molars, 
like blades, for shearing meat and sinew. Pigs have blunt, thick ones, 
useful for crushing hard roots and seeds. The myriad molars of modern mammals can be traced back to a common form
called “tribosphenic," which first appeared 
during the dinosaur age. In the 19th Century, 
paleontologist Edward Drinker Cope developed the basic model 
for how this form evolved. He hypothesized that 
it started with a cone-like tooth, as we see in many fishes, 
amphibians, and reptiles. Small cusps were then added, 
so the tooth had three in a row, aligned front to back,
and connected by crests. Over time, the cusps were pushed out 
of line to make triangular crowns. Adjacent teeth formed a continuous 
zigzag of crests for slicing and dicing. A low shelf then formed 
at the back of each set of teeth, which became a platform for crushing. As Cope realized, the tribosphenic molar 
served as the jumping-off point for the radiation of specialized
forms to follow, each shaped by evolutionary needs. Straighten the crests 
and remove the shelf, and you’ve got the conveniently 
bladed teeth of cats and dogs. Remove the front cusp, raise the shelf, 
and you’ve got our human molars. A few additional tweaks get you 
a horse or cow tooth. Some details in Cope’s intuitive
hypothesis proved wrong. But in the fossil record, there are examples of teeth 
that look just as he predicted and we can trace the molars of all living
mammals back to that primitive form. Today, the ability to consume 
diverse forms of food enables mammals to survive in habitats ranging from mountain peaks 
and ocean depths to rainforests and deserts. So the success of our biological class 
is due in no small measure to the remarkable strength 
and adaptability of the humble mammalian molar.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What gives your teeth their impressive strength?
Options: A. Teeth are comprised entirely of enamel, an extremely hard, mineralized tissue, B. Teeth are comprised entirely of dentin, a flexible tissue with tough organic fibers, C. Teeth are comprised of both hard enamel and tough dentin, D. Teeth are comprised of silica with embedded collagen fibers
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What are the two main properties that contribute to the strength of teeth? Options: A. Hardness and brittleness, B. Toughness and flexibility, C. Hardness and toughness, D. Softness and fragility Correct Option: None
Question 2: Which type of cell is responsible for secreting dentin in teeth? Options: A. Ameloblasts, B. Odontoblasts, C. Osteoblasts, D. Epithelial cells Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the main difference between the formation of enamel and dentin in teeth? Options: A. Enamel is formed by odontoblasts, while dentin is formed by ameloblasts, B. Enamel is formed by ameloblasts that slough off, while dentin is formed by odontoblasts that stick around, C. Enamel is harder than dentin, D. Dentin is more brittle than enamel Correct Option: None
Question 4: How do the teeth of different mammalian species adapt to their distinct diets? Options: A. By changing the shape of the tooth, B. By altering the folding and growth patterns of the tooth, C. By modifying the chemical composition of the tooth, D. By reducing the number of teeth Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the name of the common form of molar that first appeared during the dinosaur age? Options: A. Tribosphenic, B. Mammalian, C. Dinosaurian, D. Cretaceous Correct Option: None
Question 6: Who developed the basic model for how the tribosphenic molar evolved? Options: A. Charles Darwin, B. Edward Drinker Cope, C. Gregor Mendel, D. Louis Pasteur Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the main advantage of having teeth with both hardness and toughness? Options: A. They are more prone to cracking, B. They are more resistant to wear and tear, C. They are more brittle, D. They are more likely to break Correct Option: None
Question 8: How do the teeth of cows adapt to their diet of tough grasses? Options: A. By having sharp crested molars, B. By having flat molar teeth with parallel ridges, C. By having blunt, thick molars, D. By having no molars at all Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the result of removing the front cusp and raising the shelf of the tribosphenic molar? Options: A. The formation of cat-like teeth, B. The formation of dog-like teeth, C. The formation of human-like molars, D. The formation of horse-like teeth Correct Option: None
Question 10: Why is the ability to consume diverse forms of food important for the survival of mammals? Options: A. It allows them to live in a variety of habitats, B. It makes them more prone to disease, C. It reduces their adaptability to changing environments, D. It limits their ability to evolve Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 14, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
You may take them for granted, 
but your teeth are a marvel. They break up all your food 
over the course of your life, while being strong enough
to withstand breakage themselves. And they’re formed using 
only the raw materials from the food they grind down 
in the first place. What’s behind their impressive strength? Teeth rely on an ingenious structure 
that makes them both hard and tough. Hardness can be thought of as the ability 
to resist a crack from starting, while toughness is what stops 
the crack from spreading Very few materials have both properties. For instance, glass is hard but not tough, while leather is tough but not hard. Teeth manage both by having two layers: a hard external cap of enamel, made up
almost entirely of a calcium phosphate, and beneath it, 
a tougher layer of dentin, partly formed from organic fibers 
that make it flexible. This amazing structure is created 
by two types of cells: ameloblasts that secrete enamel and odontoblasts that secrete dentin. As they form teeth, 
odontoblasts move inward, while ameloblasts move out 
and slough off when they hit the surface. For enamel, this process produces long, 
thin strands, each about 60 nanometers in diameter. That’s one one-thousandth 
the width of a human hair. Those are bundled into rods, 
packed together, tens of thousands per square millimeter, to form the shield-like enamel layer. Once this process is finished, 
your enamel can’t repair itself again because all the cells 
that make it are lost, so we’re lucky that enamel 
can’t be easily destroyed. Odontoblasts use a more complex process,
but unlike ameloblasts, they stick around, continuing to secrete dentin 
throughout your life. Despite the differences in teeth 
across the mammalian order, the underlying process of tooth growth 
is the same whether it’s for lions, kangaroos, elephants, or us. What changes is how nature sculpts 
the shape of the tooth, altering the folding and growth patterns to suit the distinct diets 
of different species. Cows have flat molar teeth with parallel 
ridges for grinding tough grasses. Cats have sharp crested molars, 
like blades, for shearing meat and sinew. Pigs have blunt, thick ones, 
useful for crushing hard roots and seeds. The myriad molars of modern mammals can be traced back to a common form
called “tribosphenic," which first appeared 
during the dinosaur age. In the 19th Century, 
paleontologist Edward Drinker Cope developed the basic model 
for how this form evolved. He hypothesized that 
it started with a cone-like tooth, as we see in many fishes, 
amphibians, and reptiles. Small cusps were then added, 
so the tooth had three in a row, aligned front to back,
and connected by crests. Over time, the cusps were pushed out 
of line to make triangular crowns. Adjacent teeth formed a continuous 
zigzag of crests for slicing and dicing. A low shelf then formed 
at the back of each set of teeth, which became a platform for crushing. As Cope realized, the tribosphenic molar 
served as the jumping-off point for the radiation of specialized
forms to follow, each shaped by evolutionary needs. Straighten the crests 
and remove the shelf, and you’ve got the conveniently 
bladed teeth of cats and dogs. Remove the front cusp, raise the shelf, 
and you’ve got our human molars. A few additional tweaks get you 
a horse or cow tooth. Some details in Cope’s intuitive
hypothesis proved wrong. But in the fossil record, there are examples of teeth 
that look just as he predicted and we can trace the molars of all living
mammals back to that primitive form. Today, the ability to consume 
diverse forms of food enables mammals to survive in habitats ranging from mountain peaks 
and ocean depths to rainforests and deserts. So the success of our biological class 
is due in no small measure to the remarkable strength 
and adaptability of the humble mammalian molar.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The enamel layer of your tooth crowns is comprised of _______.
Options: A. Bundles of rods packed tens of thousands per square millimeter, B. Long tubules surrounding odontoblast cell bodies, C. A series of brick-like structures held together by a collagen-based mortar, D. A single, uniform tissue layer with no discrete microscopic structure
Correct Option: A

Enamel is formed by ameloblasts that slough off, while dentin is formed by odontoblasts that stick around, C. Enamel is harder than dentin, D. Dentin is more brittle than enamel Correct Option: None
Question 4: How do the teeth of different mammalian species adapt to their distinct diets? Options: A. By changing the shape of the tooth, B. By altering the folding and growth patterns of the tooth, C. By modifying the chemical composition of the tooth, D. By reducing the number of teeth Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the name of the common form of molar that first appeared during the dinosaur age? Options: A. Tribosphenic, B. Mammalian, C. Dinosaurian, D. Cretaceous Correct Option: None
Question 6: Who developed the basic model for how the tribosphenic molar evolved? Options: A. Charles Darwin, B. Edward Drinker Cope, C. Gregor Mendel, D. Louis Pasteur Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the main advantage of having teeth with both hardness and toughness? Options: A. They are more prone to cracking, B. They are more resistant to wear and tear, C. They are more brittle, D. They are more likely to break Correct Option: None
Question 8: How do the teeth of cows adapt to their diet of tough grasses? Options: A. By having sharp crested molars, B. By having flat molar teeth with parallel ridges, C. By having blunt, thick molars, D. By having no molars at all Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the result of removing the front cusp and raising the shelf of the tribosphenic molar? Options: A. The formation of cat-like teeth, B. The formation of dog-like teeth, C. The formation of human-like molars, D. The formation of horse-like teeth Correct Option: None
Question 10: Why is the ability to consume diverse forms of food important for the survival of mammals? Options: A. It allows them to live in a variety of habitats, B. It makes them more prone to disease, C. It reduces their adaptability to changing environments, D. It limits their ability to evolve Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

However, since none of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ, it's essential to note that the similarity is limited.

but your teeth are a marvel. They break up all your food 
over the course of your life, while being strong enough
to withstand breakage themselves. And they’re formed using 
only the raw materials from the food they grind down 
in the first place. What’s behind their impressive strength? Teeth rely on an ingenious structure 
that makes them both hard and tough. Hardness can be thought of as the ability 
to resist a crack from starting, while toughness is what stops 
the crack from spreading Very few materials have both properties. For instance, glass is hard but not tough, while leather is tough but not hard. Teeth manage both by having two layers: a hard external cap of enamel, made up

and ocean depths to rainforests and deserts. So the success of our biological class 
is due in no small measure to the remarkable strength 
and adaptability of the humble mammalian molar.

Options: A. The original, simple, cone-shaped structure we see today in living fishes, amphibians, and reptiles, B. A complex tooth form that combined both shearing and crushing elements, C. A recently discovered tooth form found only in early mammals that lived during the age of the dinosaurs, D. The tooth form known only for modern humans and recent human ancestors
Correct Option: B
